text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This supersedes IRM 4.70.3 dated October 30, 2018.
AUDIENCE

Acronyms: The following provides a list of acronyms and their deﬁnitions:

Acronym Deﬁnition AT Abusive Transactions BOD Business Operating Division C&CA Classiﬁcation and Case Assign- ment CP&C Compliance Planning and Classi- ﬁcation LB&I Large Business and International LDC Lead Development Center OTSA Office of Tax Shelter Analysis PSP Planning and Special Programs SB/SE Small Business and Self- Employed TE/GE Tax Exempt and Government Entities WebETS Web-Based Employee Technical Time System
investigations and is intended to complement IRM

, Abusive Transactions. IRS is committed to stopping the widespread use of abusive transactions that erode the voluntary tax compliance system and result in substantial tax revenue losses. As a partner in these efforts, TE/GE participates in pursuing investigation of promoters of these abusive transactions. These investigations are designated as priority work. The IRS combats AT promotions by:
(10-30-2018) Overview of Promoter Investigations and Deﬁnitions

TE/GE a. Seeking timely injunctions. b. Asserting civil penalties against promoters. c. Providing published guidance. d. Conducting various client compliance actions. e. Criminally prosecuting promoters or clients. (
) The term “promoter” as used throughout this IRM chapter unless speciﬁcally noted, includes promoters, material advisors as deﬁned under IRC
, tax return preparers. (

) The term “client” as used in this IRM chapter includes all persons who pated in a promotion, purchased a product or service from a promoter, had interest in a promotion, or received any material aid, assistance, or advice respect to the promotion. Client includes investors and advisees. Client also includes all persons who paid to have a tax return or tax form prepared or sought tax advice from any individual or ﬁrm offering such service or See IRM
) Abusive promotions are deﬁned and discussed in IRM

) The corporate approach is a strategy that supports TE/GE coordination • SB/SE • SB/SE Lead Development Center (LDC) • Large Business and International (LB&I) • Office of Tax Shelter Analysis (OTSA) (

) The corporate approach enables TE/GE to deter and stop promoter involving tax-exempt entities. This approach: a. Designates oversight, roles and responsibilities within management, develops a uniform strategic approach to conduct and/or facilitate effective promoter investigations. b. Develops and carries out a practical screening process to determine potential promoter investigations. The process includes coordinating SB/SE, LDC and OTSA in continually reviewing leads and referrals to identify and address promotions that involve entities and/or c. Identiﬁes and assigns needed resources (agents and support staff) for TE/GE to take the lead in applicable promoter investigations and/or provide needed support to SB/SE and other functions. (
) Managing at the corporate level involves: a. Developing a TE/GE cadre of agents to help with or lead a promoter vestigation. b. Coordinating with management to ensure cadre availability. (

) TE/GE designates the following promoter investigation positions: Position Designated Person TE/GE CP&C Program Manager TE/GE Commissioner designee TE/GE Fraud Specialist TE/GE Commissioner designee Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
G
The corporate approach enables TE/GE to deter and stop promoter schemes involving tax-exempt entities. This approach:

Designates oversight, roles and responsibilities within management, and develops a uniform strategic approach to conduct and/or facilitate effective promoter investigations. Develops and carries out a practical screening process to determine potential promoter investigations. The process includes coordinating with SB/SE, LDC and OTSA in continually reviewing leads and referrals to identify and address promotions that involve entities and/or transactions. Identiﬁes and assigns needed resources (agents and support staff) for TE/GE to take the lead in applicable promoter investigations and/or provide needed support to SB/SE and other functions.

page 3 Position Designated Person Promoter Investigation Cadre Trained agents for each TE/GE (Cadre) function to take the lead roles in promoter investigations and assist with examinations related to promoter investigations
(04-13-2021) TE/GE CP&C Program Manager and Fraud Specialist
With respect to promoter investigations, the responsibilities of the TE/GE Fraud Specialist include overseeing program-related processes across TE/GE:

TE/GE liaison to the LDC Supports agents conducting or providing examination assistance to promoter investigations Ensures regular communication occurs between TE/GE agents and agents in other BODs who are working examinations related to the promoter investigation Facilitates meetings between TE/GE and other BODs and functions to prepare and maintain active investigation action plans for each investigation. Ensures promoter investigation
related inventory is properly controlled TE/GE computerized inventory systems. Updates the LDC and OTSA on the status of open promoter investiga
tions.

) The TE/GE Fraud Specialist also resolves program needs: a. Engages in ongoing discussions with the LDC, OTSA, and functional management to identify program needs. b. Coordinates CP&C Issue ID and K-Net program involvement. c. Identiﬁes and delivers program-related training. (

) With respect to identifying and delivering program-related training: a. Assesses agent and support staff training needs b. Works with the CP&C Program Manager to identify needed training and identify resource needs. c. Coordinates training efforts within TE/GE and with other BODs and functions. d. Ensures delivery of quarterly program roundtables. (
) The SB/SE LDC receives leads. See IRM
, Identiﬁcation of Leads and IRM
, SB/SE Lead Development Center (SB/SE LDC). For processing promoter investigation leads, see Lead Development Center. (

, Promoter Referrals. (

) TE/GE supports evaluating promoter investigation leads and support needs meeting periodically with the LDC to discuss and resolve issues for TE/GE- related leads. Note: The LDC contact the TE/GE Fraud Specialist as necessary to resolve for TE/GE-related leads and support needs.

) TE/GE supports evaluating promoter investigation leads and support needs meeting periodically with the LDC to discuss and resolve issues for TE/GE- related leads. Note: The LDC contact the TE/GE Fraud Specialist as necessary to resolve for TE/GE-related leads and support needs. (

) As part of the LDC authorization and deconﬂiction process, TE/GE Division Counsel is provided an opportunity to assess the lead and provide feedback the LDC. This feedback is considered in the determination of which BOD the promoter investigation. (

) If a promoter investigation is authorized and it is determined that TE/GE be the best choice to lead the investigation, the LDC sends the approved Approval and case ﬁle to the TE/GE Fraud Specialist to evaluate the case material, for verify functional jurisdiction, and assess functional resources. a. If the TE/GE Fraud Specialist determines that the TE/GE function does not have either jurisdiction or available resources, the LDC will be of the circumstances and further discussions will be conducted to determine how best to proceed. (

) After the TE/GE Fraud Specialist determines that a TE/GE function has juris- diction and available resources, the lead is accepted, the database is and case controls are established through CP&C – Classiﬁcation & Case signment (C&CA). Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
G

) Promoter investigations led by TE/GE agents or support examinations will assigned to a trained member of its Cadre whenever possible. (
) The TE/GE Fraud Specialist will contact TE/GE Counsel for the a TE/GE Division Counsel attorney to assist with the promoter (
) If TE/GE is the lead operating division, the TE/GE Fraud Specialist will the LDC with the names of the TE/GE Lead Agent and TE/GE Division Counsel employee within
days of receiving the case ﬁle. (

) If TE/GE needs SB/SE help (legal, technical, revenue agent, or other), the TE/GE Fraud Specialist will contact the LDC who coordinates with the priate Abusive Transactions (AT) Territory Manager to provide SB/SE assistance. (

) The TE/GE Fraud Specialist : a. Provides the TE/GE Lead Agent with SB/SE points of contact for support role in TE/GE-led promoter investigations. b. Communicates at least quarterly with the TE/GE Lead agent to communication with SB/SE and Counsel during this part of the (
) The TE/GE Lead Agent develops an action plan for each promoter tion. (
) A team approach is used to conduct promoter investigations and complete exams. (

) It is important for the TE/GE Lead Agent to contact SB/SE as early in the process as possible to avoid case processing delays when there are client aminations under SB/SE jurisdiction. under a. If an SB/SE agent is needed to help with client exams, (i.e., taxable returns must be reviewed to resolve a case), the TE/GE Lead Agent prepare a Form
, Collateral Examination, request for a collateral agent or a request for the release of jurisdiction for the appropriate income tax return. b. If SB/SE is unable to begin the client exams within
days, TE/GE request SB/SE to release its jurisdiction over the clients. Note: This rule doesn’t apply to discrepancy adjustments because aren’t considered exams. (
) The Form
is emailed to the TE/GE Fraud Specialist, who will with SB/SE Planning and Special Programs (PSP) Territory Manager to SB/SE examination support, if possible. (

) If SB/SE is unable to assist, the TE/GE Fraud Specialist will follow up with SB/SE about releasing jurisdiction of the return, if warranted. Caution: nations of returns outside TE/GE jurisdiction will not be opened unless (or other BOD) has provided a written release of jurisdiction.
(10-30-2018) TE/GE Lead-Client Examinations under SB/SE Jurisdiction
If an SB/SE agent is needed to help with client exams, (i.e., taxable returns must be reviewed to resolve a case), the TE/GE Lead Agent prepare a Form
, Collateral Examination, request for a collateral agent or a request for the release of jurisdiction for the appropriate income tax return. If SB/SE is unable to begin the client exams within
days, TE/GE request SB/SE to release its jurisdiction over the clients.
The Form
is emailed to the TE/GE Fraud Specialist, who will coordinate with SB/SE Planning and Special Programs (PSP) Territory Manager to secure SB/SE examination support, if possible.
The Form

is emailed to the TE/GE Fraud Specialist, who will coordinate with SB/SE Planning and Special Programs (PSP) Territory Manager to SB/SE examination support, if possible. If SB/SE is unable to assist, the TE/GE Fraud Specialist will follow up with SB/SE about releasing jurisdiction of the return, if warranted. Caution: Exami- nations of returns outside TE/GE jurisdiction will not be opened unless SB/SE (or other BOD) has provided a written release of jurisdiction.

If SB/SE is unable to assist, the TE/GE Fraud Specialist will follow up with SB/SE about releasing jurisdiction of the return, if warranted. Caution: Exami- nations of returns outside TE/GE jurisdiction will not be opened unless (or other BOD) has provided a written release of jurisdiction.
If SB/SE is the lead operating division, the LDC will notify the TE/GE Fraud Specialist of the assigned SB/SE revenue agent and SB/SE Counsel Attorney.
After TE/GE agrees to provide support for promoter investigations involving a TE/GE entity or taxpayer, the TE/GE Fraud Specialist will fa
cilitate the assignment of the examination to a Cadre agent. SB/SB Counsel will contact TE/GE Division Counsel if additional legal support is needed.
support is needed. (
) The TE/GE Fraud Specialist is the TE/GE liaison with the LDC. (
) The TE/GE Fraud Specialist will ensure that SB/SE notiﬁes TE/GE of points of contact. (
) The TE/GE Fraud Specialist will regularly communicate with the assigned TE/GE agent(s) to ensure TE/GE continually coordinates and develops the case with SB/SE and Counsel. (

) The TE/GE Fraud Specialist: a. Communicates with the LDC and appropriate SB/SE management to ensure they include the TE/GE agent(s) and manager(s) in their development meeting with SB/SE employees and Counsel. b. Includes the assigned TE/GE agent and group manager when ing assignments for supporting TE/GE client examinations to ensure exams are done timely. (
) A team approach to conduct promoter investigations and complete client exams is essential. (

) It’s critical to the success of any promoter investigation to address non- compliance by clients in abusive promotions and to show “harm” to the government because of the promotion. Note: Harm to the government is the loss, or potential loss, of revenue through noncompliance. (
) Occasionally, TE/GE may need to examine clients’ tax returns in promoter vestigations to substantiate harm to the government. See IRM
, Client/Investor/Advisee Lists and IRM
, Client/Investor/Advisee for compliance actions that IRS may take on clients. TE/GE may develop compliance actions for TE/GE taxpayers. (

) It is important for the TE/GE Lead Agent secure the promoter client list as early as possible in the investigation to allow time for case building and ﬁcation. Once the client list is secured, it will be sent to the TE/GE Fraud Specialist, who will share it with CP&C, C&CA to initiate the selection of examinations. (
) If the case involves SB/SE taxpayers, the TE/GE Fraud Specialist will: a. Share the list with the AT List Keeper within
days of receipt. b. Coordinate the appropriate case building requirements with in the appropriate operating divisions with the SB/SE ATAT List See IRM
, Client/Investor/ Advisee Lists for procedures to submit a list.

a. Communicates with the LDC and appropriate SB/SE management to ensure they include the TE/GE agent(s) and manager(s) in their workplan development meeting with SB/SE employees and Counsel. b. Includes the assigned TE/GE agent and group manager when coordinat
ing assignments for supporting TE/GE client examinations to ensure the exams are done timely.

) For cases that involve individual client noncompliance, the TE/GE Fraud cialist will coordinate a compliance strategy with the appropriate functions TE/GE and the other affected BODs. (
) The TE/GE Fraud Specialist ensures that case controls are established the LDC sends an authorized investigation to the TE/GE Lead Agent. a. IRC
, IRC

and IRC
penalty investigations controlled on TE/GE computer systems. b. Controls are established only for the most current fully completed calendar year. (
) Web-Based Employee Technical Time System (We
TS) is used to track promoter investigation time charges. Time applied to identiﬁcation and sion of sub-promoter leads to the LDC be charged to the key case. (
) Client examinations worked by TE/GE are controlled like other TE/GE nation cases. (

) The LDC requires the business units to provide status updates every two months for all promoter investigations. The TE/GE Fraud Specialist must complete the reports and submit them to the LDC. Examiners assigned to these investigations provide the information for the reports. (
) The TE/GE agent must contact the TE/GE Fraud Specialist for case procedures.
The TE/GE Fraud Specialist ensures that case controls are established when the LDC sends an authorized investigation to the TE/GE Lead Agent.

The LDC requires the business units to provide status updates every two months for all promoter investigations. The TE/GE Fraud Specialist must complete the reports and submit them to the LDC. Examiners assigned to these investigations provide the information for the reports.
